body.p:
Paducah Ky Nov 13 1863
To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette
Frankfort, Ky

Dear Sir. some two or three years ago & during my term of service as Equity & Criminal Judge of the first Judicial district, an Indictment was returned us Wm Wood, charging him with suffering Gaming in his House &c. upon the trial the proof showed the following facts (viz) That Wm Wood was the owner of a Coffee House in Jersey City, that a party of 4 or 5 gentlemen were at his house, and a proposition was made and acceded to engage in a game of Cards for Oysters, that a Deck of Cards was sent for and the party then played for some oysters. This was all the gaming that was established by the Evidence that Evidence also concluded to show that Mr Wood was a man of good standing and was opposed to gaming, and that none of the witnesses had ever known of any others gam
-ing in his house, upon this proof a verdict was returned vs Mr Wood accessing his fine at $200. & costs and Judgement was rendered, accordingly the Judgement has never been paid and Mr Wood was a few days since arrested & confined in Jail for a short time & some of his friends then Replevied the Judgt. Mr Wood is a very poor man about fifty years old. These facts are written at the request of Mr Wood who I understand intends applying to you for Executive Clemency

Very Respectfully
Your Obt Sevt
J. M. Bigger
The above statement of the facts in the case cited, cannot fail to convince you of the merits of the claim to executive clemency.

I have known Mr. Woods for many years and can vouch for his good conduct and strict observance of law, and I cheerfully join in the petition asking the interposition of Executive clemency, by remiting the fine

I have the honor to be Sir
Very Respectfully,
your Obt Sevt.
R. B. J. Twyman
